sourceDesc.p: M.R. James, Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge 1912

projectDesc.p: The James Catalogue was digitized then marked up following the TEI P5 Guidelines. The customized model was provided by Giuliano Di Bacco, stored in an ODD file (parkerweb.xml): the latter was written by GDB using ROMA vers. 2.x, with manual adaptations. The ODD file is used as a source to compile the actual schema used to validate the xml: it is advisable to compile it in RelaxNG sintax (parkerweb.rnc) through ROMA.

msDesc.head: Astronomical Tracts. Liber de Joseph et Aseneth
Astronomica. Aseneth, etc.
msDesc.p: Paper and vellum, 199 139 , 7.7 x 5.7, ff. MSS. 41 + 18 + 11 + 1, six volumes. Cent. xvi, xv, xii?, xiii.

Volumes I-III not imaged
Volume IV: Paper, 37 etc. lines to a page. Cent. xv in a small current hand.
Volume V: Vellum, 28 lines to a page. Cent. xii? in a hand like that of Christ Church, Canterbury.
Volume VI: Double columns of 41 lines. Cent xiii, in a good small hand.

Collation:
Volume IV: 114-314 (wants 14).
Volume V: 110 210 (wants 9, 10).
Volume VI: 112 (wants 12), 1 flyleaf.

2 fo.:
Volume V: in eo et uestimenta.
ff. a-b + (printed matter, unfoliated, not imaged) + 1-70 + i + c-d.

msItem.head: Geoffrey Chaucer, Treatise on the Astrolabe

head.title: A treatise of the astrolabe made English by Chaucer for the use of his son Lewis

msItem.incipit: vnderstond well þt þe zodiake is departyd in 2 halfe circles
msItem.rubric: Explicit tractatus astrolabii secundum Chaunsers factus filio suo lodowyco
msItem.ab: Skeat, The Astrolabe, E.E.T.S. extra series 1872, p. xi, describes this copy

head.title: Bona improbatio Kalendarii nostri et correctio ejusdem plane

msItem.incipit: Sciendum est quod kalendarium quo utimur
msItem.rubric: Explicit bona improbacio kalendarii nostri. Et correctio eiusdem plane

msItem.head: pseudo-Hippocrates, De prognosticationibus aegritudinum secundum motum lunae (transl. byWilliam of Moerbeke)
msItem.incipit: Sapientissimus ypocras et medicorum optimus ait

msItem.head: Arnold of Villanova (attrib.), De electione situs lune in exibendis farmacis

head.title: Compendium de existentia lunae in signis

msItem.incipit: Quoniam medicus practicans non semper potest habere certa loca planetarum
msItem.explicit: luna est in piscibus ubi est impedita
msItem.rubric: Explicit compendium de existencia lune in signis

msItem.head: Albumasar (Abu Ma'shar Ja'far) (attrib.), De secretis philosophorum
msItem.incipit: In nomine dei misericordie et pietatis. hic est liber quem collegit Albumazar de floribus philosophorum, etc.
msItem.rubric: Expliciunt flores Albumasar de secretis philosophorum

msItem.head: Robert Grosseteste, De impressionibus aeris siue De prognosticatione

head.title: Robertus Grostest Lincolniensis de prognosticatione aeris

msItem.incipit: Cum circa(?) disposicionem aeris ad aliquod certum tempus

head.title: Regimen sanitatis Salernitanum (Flos medicinae scholae Salerni)

msItem.incipit: Anglorum regi scripsit scola tota salerni
msItem.explicit: que super renes pecten des fitque iuuamen
msItem.ab: See Dr N. Moore, Schola Salernitana (Finlayson Lecture), Glasgow 1908, p. 27

head.title: A treatise of medicine or dispensatory by Nycolas

msItem.incipit: I nycolas y prevyd of some men and felawes of practyce
msItem.ab: The antidotarium of Nicholaus in English, ending imperfectly in Electuarium leticia galieni

head.title: De Asenath filia Potipharis sacerdotis et quo ordine accepit eam Joseph in uxorem

msItem.rubric: Incipit de Asenech filia Putifaris sacerdotis et quo ordine accepit eam Ioseph in uxorem
msItem.incipit: Et factum est in primo anno septem annorum
msItem.ab: The edges have been much cropped, carrying away the upper or lower line in part
msItem.explicit: nuncupatus est pater eius in terra Egypti
msItem.ab: This text is printed in Batiffol, Studia Patristica I 1889, pp. 89-115: collated with the text of no. 288

This is the oldest copy of the text I have seen. If it is really of cent. xii, as seems likely, it is impossible that Robert Grosseteste should (as I have always been inclined to believe) have had a hand in the translation of the text from Greek into Latin

msItem.head: Thomas de Frakaham OSA, Speculum spiritalis amicitiae
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber qui dicitur speculum spiritualis amicitie
msItem.incipit: Primum quid sit amicicia arbitror disserendum
msItem.explicit: apud iustum et misericordem iudicem intercedat
msItem.rubric: Explicit liber IIIus de spirituali amicicia. hanc compilacionem fecit dominus Thomas de frakaham canonicus de lesnes. compilauit autem hec de libris aluredi abbatis Reuallis, i. de speculo caritatis et de libro spiritualis amicicie
msItem.ab: Lesnes (or Westwood) was an Augustinian priory near Woolwich

msItem.head: pseudo-Aelred of Rievaulx OCist, Speculum humilitatis
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber qui dicitur speculum humilitatis
msItem.incipit: Dominus noster Ihesu Christus dicit discipulis suis in ewangelio. Nolite in sublime tolli
msItem.explicit: humilitatem exhibuit. beatus saluator Christus Ihesus qui cum patre et spiritu sancto uiuit et regnat in secula seculorum. Amen
msItem.ab: This tract is noticed in Bale's Index, pp. 470,480. In the former place it is ascribed to a monk of Syon. It occurs in the Syon Catalogue under S.43
The flyleaf is from a beautifully written xiith cent. copy of the Gospels containing part of Matt. xvi., xvii
